question:
On which date did Punjab abolish the Legislative Council?

SSC MTS 30/09/2024 (1st Shift)
solution:
• The Legislative Council (Vidhan Parishad) in Punjab was abolished on 1 January 1970.
  • This was done under the provisions of Article 169 of the Indian Constitution, which empowers Parliament to create or abolish a State Legislative Council based on a resolution passed by the concerned State Legislative Assembly with a special majority.
  • Punjab became a unicameral legislature (with only the Legislative Assembly) after the abolition.

Extra Insights:

  • Parliament passed the Punjab Legislative Council (Abolition) Act, 1969, which came into effect on 1 January 1970.
  • Other states like West Bengal and Andhra Pradesh have also abolished their Legislative Councils at different times.

question:
The ‘Rule of Law’ is a key feature of the Indian Constitution which is a doctrine ascribed to _____________.

SSC MTS 14/10/2024 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• The concept of the ‘Rule of Law’ is a fundamental doctrine of the Indian Constitution, ensuring that no one is above the law.
  • This principle was propounded by British jurist Albert Venn Dicey.
  • According to Dicey, the Rule of Law has three core elements:
    1. Supremacy of law – No person can be punished except for a breach of law.
    2. Equality before law – All individuals are subject to the same law.
    3. Predominance of legal spirit – The Constitution is the result of ordinary law, not the source of it.

Extra Insights:

  • The Rule of Law is part of the basic structure of the Indian Constitution.
  • It is reflected in Articles 14 (equality before law) and 21 (protection of life and liberty).

question:
The National Population Register was created under the provisions of ___________ and ___________ .

a. the Citizenship Act, 1965

b. the Citizenship Rules, 2004

c. the Citizenship Act, 1955

d. the Citizenship Rules, 2003

SSC MTS 05/11/2024 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• The National Population Register (NPR) is a register of the usual residents of the country, maintained by the Registrar General and Census Commissioner of India.
  • It is created under the provisions of:
    • The Citizenship Act, 1955
    • The Citizenship Rules, 2003
  • A “usual resident” is someone who has resided in a local area for the past 6 months or intends to stay there for the next 6 months or more.

Extra Insights:

  • NPR is different from Census – Census collects demographic data, while NPR links it with citizenship records.
  • NPR is the first step toward creating the National Register of Citizens (NRC).

question:
Which party formed the government in Britain in the year 1945?

SSC CGL 11/09/2024 (1st Shift)
solution:
• In the year 1945, following the end of World War II, Britain held a general election.
  • The Labour Party, led by Clement Attlee, won a landslide victory and formed the government.
  • This election marked a major political shift, ending Winston Churchill’s wartime Conservative rule.
  • The Labour Party introduced several welfare-state reforms, including the National Health Service (NHS) and expanded social security.

Extra Insights:

  • The 1945 victory gave Labour 393 out of 640 seats in the House of Commons.
  • This was the first time the Labour Party secured an outright majority in Parliament.

question:
The concept of Public Interest Litigation originated in _______________.

SSC CGL 12/09/2024 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• The concept of Public Interest Litigation (PIL) originated in the United States of America (USA).
  • In the U.S., PIL emerged as a tool in the 1960s–70s civil rights movement to allow individuals or groups to approach courts for the protection of public interest and constitutional rights.
  • In India, PIL was adopted and expanded primarily through judicial activism in the 1980s, pioneered by Justice P.N. Bhagwati and Justice V.R. Krishna Iyer.

Extra Insights:

  • PIL allows any public-spirited individual to file a case on behalf of those whose rights are violated.
  • In India, it has been used for issues like environmental protection, bonded labour, prison reforms, etc.
  • Article 32 (Supreme Court) and 226 (High Courts) are constitutional provisions used for PILs.

question:
Dr. B. R. Ambedkar described Directive Principles of State Policy as __________of the Indian constitution.

SSC CGL 13/09/2024 (3rd Shift)
option_1: soul of the state
option_2: identity card of the constitution
option_3: The most precious part of the constitution
option_4: a novel feature of the constitution
solution:
• Dr. B.R. Ambedkar, the chief architect of the Indian Constitution, described the Directive Principles of State Policy (DPSPs) as a "novel feature of the Constitution".
  • These principles are included in Part IV (Articles 36 to 51) of the Constitution.
  • DPSPs aim to guide the State in making laws and policies that ensure social and economic justice.
  • Though non-justiciable (not enforceable in court), they are fundamental in the governance of the country.

Extra Insights:

  • DPSPs are inspired by the Irish Constitution.
  • Examples include promotion of equal pay, free education, nutrition, and environmental protection.
  • They complement Fundamental Rights and reflect the ideals of a welfare state.

question:
The British Parliament introduced the Indian High Courts Act in which year?

SSC CGL 17/09/2024 (1st Shift)
solution:
• The Indian High Courts Act was introduced by the British Parliament in the year 1861.
  • This Act allowed the establishment of High Courts in the major presidency towns — Calcutta, Bombay, and Madras.
  • It replaced the earlier Supreme Courts and Sadar Adalats that existed during colonial rule.
  • The High Courts created under this Act were empowered to exercise both original and appellate jurisdiction in civil and criminal matters.

Extra Insights:

  • The first High Court was established in Calcutta on 1 July 1862, followed by Bombay and Madras.
  • The Act marked the beginning of the modern judicial system in India.
  • The High Courts functioned under a Charter issued by the British Crown.

question:
Which of the following statements is correct with respect to the political parties in India?

SSC CGL 18/09/2024 (2nd Shift)
option_1: A political party symbol is assigned by the President of India.
option_2: India has a multi-party system classified as national, state or regional level
option_3: All parties are registered with the Supreme Court of India
option_4: Status of party is accorded by the Parliament.
solution:
• The correct statement about political parties in India is:

(b) India has a multi-party system classified as national, state or regional level.

  • India follows a multi-party system, meaning multiple parties compete at national and state levels.
  • The Election Commission of India (ECI) classifies political parties as:
    • National Parties
    • State Parties
    • Registered Unrecognised Parties

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (a) Political symbols are not assigned by the President, but by the Election Commission.
  • (c) Political parties are registered with the Election Commission, not the Supreme Court.
  • (d) Party status is not granted by Parliament, but by the Election Commission based on performance.

Extra Insights:

  • Recognition depends on vote percentage, seats won, and performance in elections.
  • As of recent elections, India has 8 national parties including BJP, INC, AAP, etc.

question:
In which of the following years was the Right of Persons with Disabilities Act passed?

SSC CGL 19/09/2024 (1st Shift)
solution:
• The Right of Persons with Disabilities Act was passed in the year 2016.
  • This Act replaced the earlier Persons with Disabilities (Equal Opportunities, Protection of Rights and Full Participation) Act, 1995.
  • It was enacted to comply with the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, which India ratified in 2007.
  • The 2016 Act aims to empower and ensure dignity, equality, and full participation of persons with disabilities.

Extra Insights:

  • The number of recognized disabilities under this Act increased from 7 to 21, including autism, cerebral palsy, thalassemia, etc.
  • It mandates reservation of 4% in government jobs and 5% in higher education institutions for persons with benchmark disabilities.

question:
When did a States Reorganisation Commission was set up, which recommended the creation of linguistic States on the basis of larger linguistic groups?

SSC CGL 25/09/2024 (1st Shift)
solution:
• The States Reorganisation Commission was set up in December 1953 by the Government of India.
  • Its purpose was to examine the reorganization of states in India, primarily on linguistic lines.
  • The commission was headed by Fazl Ali, with K.M. Panikkar and H.N. Kunzru as members.
  • It submitted its report in 1955, which led to the enactment of the States Reorganisation Act, 1956.

Extra Insights:

  • The States Reorganisation Act, 1956 came into effect on 1 November 1956, redrawing the map of India.
  • This led to the creation of linguistic states like Andhra Pradesh, Kerala, Karnataka, and Maharashtra.

question:
Which of the following states is one of those states that have no Panchayati Raj Institution at all?

SSC CGL 25/09/2024 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• The correct answer is Nagaland, which does not have a Panchayati Raj Institution (PRI).
  • The 73rd Constitutional Amendment Act, 1992, which gave constitutional status to PRIs, does not apply to certain areas, including Nagaland.
  • This exclusion is due to the special provisions under Article 243M and Article 371A, which safeguard the customary laws and local practices of Nagaland’s tribal communities.

Extra Insights:

  • Other areas exempted from the 73rd Amendment include Mizoram, Meghalaya, and certain Scheduled and Tribal Areas under the Sixth Schedule.
  • In place of PRIs, traditional village councils governed by local customs manage administration in Nagaland.

question:
The Citizenship Act, 1955 does NOT deal with ____________.

SSC CHSL 02/07/2024 (3rd shift)
solution:
• The Citizenship Act, 1955 lays down the legal provisions regarding citizenship in India.
  • It deals with five main aspects:
    1. Acquisition of citizenship
    2. Termination of citizenship
    3. Renunciation of citizenship
    4. Citizenship by birth, descent, registration, and naturalisation
    5. Determination of citizenship (in case of doubt)
  • However, it does not deal with elections, which fall under the Representation of the People Act, 1951.

Extra Insights:

  • The Ministry of Home Affairs administers this Act through the Foreigners Division and Citizenship Division.
  • Amendments to this Act include the 2003 and 2019 amendments, the latter being associated with the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA).

question:
Which Section of the Representation of People’s Act (RPA), 1951 deprives the prisoners of their right to vote?

SSC CHSL 03/07/2024 (3rd shift)
solution:
• The Representation of the People Act (RPA), 1951, governs elections in India.
  • Section 62(5) of the Act prohibits prisoners from voting in elections.
  • It states that no person shall vote if he is confined in prison, whether under a sentence of imprisonment or under preventive detention, except if he is in custody during trial (i.e., under-trial prisoners are excluded).

Extra Insights:

  • This rule has been upheld by the Supreme Court, citing that the right to vote is a statutory right, not a fundamental right.
  • This provision has been subject to debate, with some critics calling it discriminatory and demanding reforms.

question:
The proclamation of which Act by the King of England in 1773 paved the way for the establishment of the Supreme Court at Calcutta?

SSC CHSL 03/07/2024 (3rd shift)
solution:
• The Regulating Act of 1773 was proclaimed by the King of England to regulate the administration of the East India Company in India.
  • One of its key provisions was the establishment of the Supreme Court at Calcutta in 1774, marking the beginning of formal British judiciary in India.
  • This court had jurisdiction over British subjects and company officials in Bengal.

Extra Insights:

  • The Regulating Act also created the position of the Governor-General of Bengal, with Warren Hastings as the first to hold this post.
  • The Act aimed to curb corruption and bring accountability to the East India Company’s rule.

question:
Which directive principle has been implemented in establishing Handloom and Handicrafts Boards?

SSC CHSL 05/07/2024 (2nd shift)
option_1: Participation of workers in management of Industries
option_2: Provision for just and humane condition of work
option_3: Protection and improvement of environment
option_4: Promote cottage industries on cooperative basis
solution:
• The establishment of Handloom and Handicrafts Boards relates to the Directive Principle that encourages:

(d) Promote cottage industries on cooperative basis

  • This principle is enshrined in Article 43 of the Indian Constitution.
  • It directs the State to promote cottage industries in rural areas, especially on cooperative lines, for economic development and employment generation.

Extra Insights:

  • Article 43 is part of the Gandhian principles under the Directive Principles of State Policy.
  • The Handloom and Handicrafts Boards aim to preserve traditional crafts, support rural artisans, and strengthen self-reliance in villages.

question:
Which south-eastern Dravidian language has been approved by Odisha state to be included in the Eighth Schedule of the Constitution of India, on 10th July 2023 ?

SSC CHSL 08/07/2024 (1st shift)
solution:
• The Kui language, a South-Eastern Dravidian language spoken by the Kandha (Kondh) tribal community in Odisha, was approved by the Odisha state cabinet on 10th July 2023 for inclusion in the Eighth Schedule of the Constitution of India.
  • Kui is primarily spoken in Odisha and is traditionally written using the Odia script.

Extra Insights:

  • The inclusion of Kui in the Eighth Schedule aims to preserve, promote, and propagate the language and its associated culture.
  • This decision is expected to benefit over seven lakh Kui-speaking indigenous people in Odisha.

question:
Which of the following organisation’s initiative is ‘India Justice Report’?

SSC CHSL 08/07/2024 (2nd shift)
solution:
• India Justice Report (IJR) is an initiative of Tata Trusts
  • It evaluates how states and union territories perform in delivering justice through four pillars: police, judiciary, prisons, and legal aid
  • The data used in the report is sourced from official government records
  • The purpose is to highlight gaps and encourage improvement in the justice system
  • It provides a ranking of states based on justice delivery performance

Additional Information:

  • The first India Justice Report was released in 2019
  • It is developed in collaboration with:

    • Centre for Social Justice

    • Commonwealth Human Rights Initiative (CHRI)

    • DAKSH

    • Prayas (TISS)

question:
Which of the following is NOT a way to acquire citizenship in India ?

SSC CHSL 09/07/2024 (2nd shift)
solution:
• Renunciation is a way to give up Indian citizenship, not to acquire it
  • Citizenship in India can be acquired through the following five methods as per the Citizenship Act, 1955:
    1. By Birth
    2. By Descent
    3. By Registration
    4. By Naturalisation
    5. By Incorporation of Territory
  • Hence, Renunciation does not fall under the category of acquisition, but rather under termination of citizenship

Additional Information:

  • Renunciation is covered under Section 8 of the Citizenship Act
  • Other two ways of losing citizenship include termination (automatically losing citizenship) and deprivation (compulsory cancellation by the government)
  • A person above 18 can renounce Indian citizenship by declaration to the prescribed authority

question:
Which of the following is NOT a condition for acquiring the citizenship of India?

SSC CHSL 10/07/2024 (2nd shift)
solution:
• Holding property is not a legal requirement for acquiring Indian citizenship
  • Citizenship in India can be acquired through the following five methods as per the Citizenship Act, 1955:
    1. By Birth
    2. By Descent
    3. By Registration
    4. By Naturalisation
    5. By Incorporation of Territory
  • Options (a), (b), and (c) are all valid routes or criteria related to acquiring citizenship
  • Domicile plays a key role in naturalisation and registration but owning property is not required

Additional Information

  • The Citizenship Act, 1955 does not mention land or property ownership as a condition
  • Foreigners can acquire Indian citizenship only by fulfilling the specified legal processes, not by mere property investment
  • Many developed countries offer citizenship or residency in exchange for property investment, but India does not follow this model

question:
Which of the following is a feature of Directive Principles of State Policy, and also distinguishes it from Fundamental Rights ?

SSC CHSL 10/07/2024 (2nd shift)
option_2: It protects the interest of the individual.
option_3: It is non- justiciable.
option_4: It is prohibitive in nature.
solution:
• Directive Principles of State Policy (DPSPs) are non-justiciable, meaning they cannot be enforced by any court
  • This is a key feature that distinguishes DPSPs from Fundamental Rights, which are justiciable and legally enforceable
  • DPSPs are found in Part IV (Article 36 to 51) of the Indian Constitution
  • Their aim is to guide the government in making laws and policies toward achieving social and economic justice
  • Though not enforceable, they are fundamental in governance and help in establishing a welfare state

Additional Information

  • The concept of DPSPs was borrowed from the Irish Constitution
  • Examples of DPSPs include provisions for equal pay for equal work, free legal aid, promotion of education, and organization of village panchayats
  • Article 37 clearly states that DPSPs are not enforceable in any court, but they are nevertheless fundamental in the governance of the country

question:
Any citizen of India can make a declaration renouncing his/her Indian citizenship under the ________.

SSC CHSL 11/07/2024 (2nd shift)
solution:
Solution
  • The Citizenship Act, 1955 is the primary law that governs matters related to Indian citizenship
  • Under Section 8 of this Act, any Indian citizen of full age and capacity can make a declaration to renounce his/her citizenship
  • Once the declaration is accepted by the prescribed authority, the person ceases to be a citizen of India
  • This provision is particularly relevant when individuals acquire foreign citizenship and no longer wish to retain Indian nationality
  • The Act provides detailed procedures for acquisition, termination, and renunciation of citizenship

Additional Information

  • The Citizenship Act, 1955 has been amended multiple times, most recently by the Citizenship Amendment Act, 2019 (CAA)
  • Along with renunciation, the Act also provides for termination (automatic loss) and deprivation (government cancellation) of citizenship
  • Renunciation is a voluntary act, while termination or deprivation can occur under certain legal circumstances

question:
Which of the following Sections of the Indian Penal Code deals with 'rape'?

SSC CHSL 11/07/2024 (3rd shift)
solution:
Solution
  • Section 375 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) defines the offence of rape
  • It explains what constitutes rape, including sexual intercourse without consent, or under coercion, fraud, or when the woman is incapable of giving consent (e.g., due to intoxication or mental illness)
  • The section was amended by the Criminal Law (Amendment) Act, 2013, after the Nirbhaya case, to broaden its scope
  • The amendment expanded the definition to include acts beyond traditional intercourse, addressing modern forms of sexual assault
  • It also introduced stricter punishment under Section 376, which deals with the penalty for rape

Additional Information

  • Section 375 only defines the offence, while Section 376 prescribes the punishment, which can range from a minimum of 10 years to life imprisonment
  • Consent must be clear, voluntary, and informed; mere silence or lack of resistance is not considered consent
  • Other related sections include:

    • Section 376A–376E – deal with aggravated forms of rape and custodial rape

    • POCSO Act, 2012 – deals with sexual offences against children

question:
Who is the Chief Executive Head of the State ?

SSC CPO 29/06/2024 (1st shift)
solution:
Solution
  • In the Indian federal structure, "State" refers to the individual states like Uttar Pradesh, Tamil Nadu, etc.
  • The Governor is the constitutional head and chief executive of a state, appointed by the President of India
  • The Governor acts as the nominal head, similar to how the President is the nominal head at the national level
  • The real executive powers in a state lie with the Chief Minister and the Council of Ministers, but the Governor exercises them in their name
  • The Governor also holds powers related to legislation, administration, and emergency situations

Additional Information

  • The Governor is appointed under Article 155 of the Indian Constitution
  • The tenure of a Governor is 5 years, but he/she holds office at the pleasure of the President
  • A Governor must be a citizen of India and at least 35 years old
  • The same person can be appointed as Governor for two or more states simultaneously

question:
How many members (elected and nominated) were there in the Council of State under the Government of India Act 1919 passed by the Parliament of the United Kingdom to expand participation of Indians in the government of India?

SSC CPO 29/06/2024 (2nd shift)
solution:
Solution
  • The Government of India Act, 1919, also known as the Montagu-Chelmsford Reforms, aimed to increase Indian involvement in governance
  • This Act introduced a bicameral legislature at the centre:
    1. Council of State (Upper House)
    2. Legislative Assembly (Lower House)
  • The Council of State was to consist of 60 members in total:

    • 34 elected members

    • 26 nominated members

  • These reforms marked a shift towards diarchy in provinces and limited self-government

Additional Information

  • The Act came into effect in 1921
  • It laid the foundation for responsible government, though real power remained with the British
  • The Legislative Assembly had 145 members, with a mix of elected and nominated representatives
  • The next major constitutional development after this was the Government of India Act, 1935, which provided for a federal structure

question:
Which of the following was widely considered as the ‘heaven born service’ for Indians during British rule?

SSC CPO 29/06/2024 (3rd shift)
option_1: Military service on the Burma front
option_2: The Indian Civil Service or ICS
option_3: The Indian Judicial Service
option_4: The British Indian Army
solution:
• The Indian Civil Service (ICS) was regarded as the most elite and prestigious service under British rule
  • It was known as the "Heaven Born Service" because of the immense status, power, and privileges associated with it
  • ICS officers were entrusted with key roles in administration, revenue collection, and law enforcement across British India
  • Initially, the service was dominated by British officers, and only a few Indians were able to enter after the exams were opened to them in the mid-19th century
  • Passing the ICS exam, held in London, was extremely challenging and was seen as a mark of intellectual excellence

Additional Information

  • The ICS was formalized through the Charter Act of 1853, which introduced competitive exams for recruitment
  • The first Indian to join the ICS was Satyendranath Tagore in 1863
  • After independence, the ICS evolved into the Indian Administrative Service (IAS)
  • The ICS played a crucial role in executing the British government's policies and maintaining colonial control

question:
During a National Emergency, the term of Lok Sabha can be extended for:

Matriculation Level 20/06/2024 (Shift- 1)
option_1: three months at a time
option_2: six months at a time
option_3: one year at a time
option_4: two years at a time
solution:
• Under Article 83(2) of the Indian Constitution, the normal term of the Lok Sabha is 5 years
  • However, during a National Emergency, Parliament is empowered to extend its term
  • The extension can be done by law, but only one year at a time
  • Even during an emergency, the Lok Sabha cannot be extended indefinitely—it must be dissolved within six months after the emergency ends
  • This ensures democratic continuity while allowing temporary suspension of elections for national stability

Additional Information

  • National Emergency is declared under Article 352 due to war, external aggression, or armed rebellion
  • The last such extension of Lok Sabha occurred during the Emergency period (1975–77) under Indira Gandhi's government
  • Even though elections are delayed, democratic structure is maintained through constitutional provisions

question:
The Prevention of Seditious Meetings Act was passed in ________ by the colonial Government.

Matriculation Level 24/06/2024 (Shift- 4)
solution:
• The Prevention of Seditious Meetings Act, 1907 was enacted by the British colonial government in India
  • It was passed to curb nationalist gatherings and prevent the spread of seditious ideas against British rule
  • The Act restricted public meetings where political subjects were discussed, particularly those criticizing the British government
  • Authorities could regulate or prohibit assemblies, especially in disturbed areas
  • This law was part of a series of repressive legislations passed to suppress the freedom movement

Additional Information

  • The Act was influenced by the growing Swadeshi Movement and revolutionary activities following the Partition of Bengal (1905)
  • It gave the district magistrate the power to require prior permission for holding public meetings
  • Other similar laws include:

    • The Explosive Substances Act (1908)

    • The Indian Press Act (1910)

  • These laws reflected the colonial government's fear of mass political awakening in India

question:
The entire salaries, allowances and pensions of the chairman and members of the Union Public Service Commission are charged on the ______.

Matriculation Level 26/06/2024 (Shift- 1)
option_1: Consolidated fund of India
option_2: Special Fund of the UPSC
option_3: Contingency fund of India
option_4: Reserve Bank of India
solution:
• The Consolidated Fund of India is the chief government account from which all government expenditures are made
  • The salaries, allowances, and pensions of the Chairman and members of the UPSC are charged on this fund
  • This means these expenses are not subject to vote in Parliament, ensuring the independence of the UPSC
  • The provision is made to protect constitutional bodies like UPSC from political pressure
  • This financial security is laid out in Article 322 of the Indian Constitution

Additional Information

  • Charged expenditure is different from voted expenditure: charged items are automatically granted
  • Other constitutional bodies like the Election Commission and Comptroller and Auditor General (CAG) also have their expenses charged on the Consolidated Fund
  • This mechanism ensures autonomy and impartial functioning of these key institutions

question:
Who among the following was the first chairperson of National Commission for Women and a senior congress leader who passed away in 2022?

Matriculation Level 26/06/2024 (Shift- 1)
solution:
• Jayanti Patnaik was the first chairperson of the National Commission for Women (NCW), serving from 3 February 1992 to 30 January 1995 .
  • She was a senior leader of the Indian National Congress and a renowned social worker.
  • Patnaik was elected to the Lok Sabha multiple times, representing constituencies like Cuttack and Berhampur, and was also nominated to the Rajya Sabha .
  • She passed away on 28 September 2022 at the age of 90 in Bhubaneswar, Odisha .

Additional Information

  • Born on 7 April 1932 in Aska, Ganjam district, Odisha, she pursued her postgraduate studies in social work at the Tata Institute of Social Sciences, Mumbai .
  • She was married to Janaki Ballabh Patnaik, a prominent Congress leader and former Chief Minister of Odisha .
  • Apart from her political career, she was known for her literary contributions, including translating K.M. Munshi's "Krishnavatara" into Odia .

question:
Which of the following is the proposed successor to the Information Technology Act, 2000?

Higher Secondary 24/06/2024 (Shift- 2)
solution:
• The Digital India Bill is the proposed legislation intended to replace the Information Technology Act, 2000, which has become outdated due to rapid technological advancements .
  • The new bill aims to address contemporary challenges in the digital landscape, including cybersecurity threats, data protection, online safety, and the regulation of emerging technologies like artificial intelligence and digital platforms .
  • It seeks to establish a comprehensive legal framework to ensure a safe, trusted, and accountable internet environment in India .

Additional Information

  • The Digital India Bill is part of a broader initiative to modernize India's digital laws, aligning them with global standards and addressing the complexities of the current digital ecosystem.
  • Key features proposed in the bill include:
    • Classification of intermediaries based on risk assessment to implement tailored regulations.
    • Establishment of a dedicated internet regulatory authority for effective governance.
    • Designation of certain online activities as punishable offenses, such as the dissemination of misinformation and cyberbullying.
    • Revisions to existing platform rules, including a re-evaluation of the "safe harbour" provisions that currently offer legal immunity to intermediaries under certain conditions .
  • As of now, the Digital India Bill is in the consultation phase, with the government engaging stakeholders to refine its provisions before formal enactment .

question:
Which of the following does NOT come under Directive Principles of State Policy?

Graduate Level 26/06/2024 (Shift- 3)
option_1: Promotion of the Welfare of the People
option_2: Promotion of Indian Local Languages
option_4: Promotion of Cottage Industries
solution:
• Directive Principles of State Policy (DPSPs) are mentioned in Part IV (Articles 36 to 51) of the Indian Constitution
  • These principles aim to guide the State in governance to ensure social and economic justice
  • Options (a), (c), and (d) are clearly listed as part of the DPSPs:
    • (a) Promotion of welfare of the people – Article 38
    • (c) Uniform Civil Code – Article 44
    • (d) Promotion of cottage industries – Article 43
  • However, Promotion of Indian Local Languages is not included in the DPSPs; it is related to Part XVII of the Constitution, which deals with Official Language provisions

Additional Information

  • Promotion of Indian languages is covered under Articles 344 to 351, not Part IV
  • Article 351 directs the Union to promote the spread of Hindi and encourage the enrichment of other Indian languages
  • DPSPs are non-justiciable, meaning they are not enforceable in court but are fundamental to governance

question:
The ‘Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana’ (‘PM-JAY’) scheme of the government is associated with which of the following Directive Principles of State Policy ?

SSC CHSL Tier II 02/11/2023
option_1: Participation of workers in the management of industries
option_2: Promotion of co-operative societies
option_3: Equal justice and free legal aid
option_4: Duty of State to raise the level of nutrition and the improvement of public health
solution:
• The Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana (PM-JAY), also known as Ayushman Bharat, is a flagship health insurance scheme by the Government of India
  • It aims to provide financial protection for secondary and tertiary healthcare to vulnerable families
  • This aligns with Article 47 of the Directive Principles of State Policy, which states that the State shall raise the level of nutrition, standard of living, and improve public health
  • The scheme promotes universal access to healthcare and reflects the State’s responsibility toward public welfare

Additional Information

  • PM-JAY provides health coverage of ₹5 lakh per family per year for hospitalization in empanelled public and private hospitals
  • It covers more than 50 crore beneficiaries, mainly from economically weaker sections
  • Article 47 is a key DPSP that directs the State to consider health and nutrition as top priorities in policymaking

question:
Certain provisions of the Benami Transactions (Prohibition) Act were struck off by the Supreme Court. In which year was this law originally enacted?

SSC Stenographer 12/10/2023 (Evening)
solution:
• The Benami Transactions (Prohibition) Act was originally enacted in 1988.
  • It was passed to prohibit benami transactions and the right to recover property held benami.
  • However, the Act remained largely ineffective due to the absence of rules and an implementation mechanism.
  • In 2016, the Act was amended and renamed as The Prohibition of Benami Property Transactions Act, 1988, with stricter provisions.
  • In August 2022, the Supreme Court struck down certain retrospective penal provisions of the 2016 amendment as unconstitutional.

Additional Information:

  • Benami Transaction: A transaction where property is held by one person but paid for by another.
  • The law empowers authorities to seize benami properties and prosecute offenders.

question:
Who among the following founded an expatriate Communist Party of India at Tashkent in 1920?

SSC CPO 03/10/2023 (Afternoon)
solution:
• The expatriate Communist Party of India was founded at Tashkent in 1920.
  • It was established by M.N. Roy, a prominent Indian revolutionary and political thinker.
  • M.N. Roy was the first Indian to be elected to the Communist International (Comintern).
  • The party was formed abroad due to strict British surveillance and repression of leftist movements in India.
  • Tashkent, in present-day Uzbekistan (then part of Soviet Russia), provided a safe haven for revolutionary activity.

Additional Information:

  • M.N. Roy’s full name was Manabendra Nath Roy.
  • He later became critical of orthodox communism and developed the philosophy of Radical Humanism.
  • The Communist Party of India (CPI) was formally established in India in 1925 at Kanpur.

question:
Which of the following Acts prevents disrespect to the National Flag and National Anthem?

SSC CPO 03/10/2023 (Evening)
option_1: Prevention of insults to National Honour Act, 1971
option_3: Protection of National Honour Act, 1996
solution:
• The correct answer is (a) Prevention of Insults to National Honour Act, 1971.
  • This Act was enacted to prevent disrespect or insult to the National Flag, the Constitution of India, and the National Anthem.
  • It criminalizes actions such as burning, mutilating, defacing, or insulting the National Flag or National Anthem.
  • The Act applies to all Indian citizens and entities, both within and outside India.
  • Violations can result in imprisonment up to three years, a fine, or both.

Additional Information:

  • The law was passed in the context of rising concerns about national symbols being disrespected during protests or events.
  • In 2005, a specific Flag Code of India was introduced to regulate the use and display of the national flag.
  • The Supreme Court of India has upheld the constitutional validity of this Act.

question:
In the Interim Government formed on 2 September 1946, Liaquat Ali Khan was given the charge of:

SSC CPO 05/10/2023 (Afternoon)
option_1: the External Affairs Ministry
solution:
• In the Interim Government formed on 2 September 1946, Liaquat Ali Khan was appointed as the Finance Minister.
  • The Interim Government was set up under the provisions of the Cabinet Mission Plan.
  • Liaquat Ali Khan was a prominent leader of the Muslim League and represented their interests in the government.
  • His role as Finance Minister became controversial due to his budget proposals, which were seen as favoring Muslim-majority areas.
  • This appointment was a key moment in the growing political divide between the Indian National Congress and the Muslim League.

Additional Information:

  • Jawaharlal Nehru was the Vice President of the Executive Council and handled External Affairs and Commonwealth.
  • Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel was in charge of Home Affairs and Information and Broadcasting.
  • The Interim Government functioned until 15 August 1947, when India became independent.

question:
Consider the following statement about the Government of India Act, 1935.

This act was enacted by the British Parliament.

2. This Act was divided into two separate acts for the India and Burma Government.

3. This act commenced from 1 April 1935.

Select the correct statement(s) using the code given below.

SSC MTS 04/09/2023 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• Statement 1: This act was enacted by the British Parliament – ✔️Correct

    The Government of India Act, 1935 was indeed passed by the British Parliament and was the longest legislation passed by them for British India.

  • Statement 2: This Act was divided into two separate acts for the India and Burma Government – ✔️Correct

    The Act led to the separation of Burma (now Myanmar) from British India. A separate Government of Burma Act, 1935 was also enacted.

  • Statement 3: This act commenced from 1 April 1935 – ❌Incorrect

    The Government of India Act, 1935 did not commence on 1 April 1935. It came into operation in parts starting from 1937.

Correct Answer: (a) Both 1 and 2

Additional Information:

  • The Act provided for establishment of an All-India Federation, though it was never implemented.
  • It introduced provincial autonomy and abolished dyarchy at the provincial level.
  • This Act served as the basis for the Constitution of independent India to a great extent.
